module.title: Communication and Boundaries
module.description: Learn how to communicate feelings, set boundaries, and practice healthy relationship skills through interactive stories and activities

theme.title: Late-Night Texting
theme.context: At midnight, Sam's friend Jordan kept texting about a game. Exhausted but caring, Sam waited until morning to say, “I feel tired when I get texts after 11 PM.” Jordan understood and explained his anxiety. They agreed Jordan would text earlier, leaving both friends feeling heard and respected.
theme.question: How would you handle a situation where a friend's communication habits clash with your needs?

concepts.title: Using 'I' Statements to Express Feelings
concepts.definition: I statements are a communication tool that helps you express your feelings without blaming others by focusing on your own emotions and experiences
concepts.why_it_works: Using 'I feel' instead of 'You did' prevents the other person from immediately getting defensive and provides clarity about what is bothering you and why

tutorial.good_story: Maya felt upset when her sister borrowed her headphones without asking. Instead of yelling, she took a breath and said: 'I feel frustrated when my things are taken without permission because I was looking for them this morning. Can you please ask me next time?' Her sister apologized and promised to ask first.
tutorial.bad_story: Tom was angry about his friend canceling plans. He texted: 'You ALWAYS bail on me! You're such a flake and you obviously don't care about our friendship!' His friend felt attacked and they ended up in a huge argument that could have been avoided.

summary.summary_content: I statements help you express feelings without creating conflict. Remember the formula: 'I feel [emotion] when [situation] because [reason].' This approach takes responsibility for your emotions while clearly communicating your needs.
summary.next_chapter_intro: Now that you can express your feelings clearly, let's explore how to truly listen when others share theirs.

quizzes.question: Your friend keeps interrupting you during conversations. Which is the best 'I' statement to address this?
options: You never let me finish talking!
I feel frustrated when I'm interrupted because I lose my train of thought
Stop being so rude all the time
Why can't you just listen for once?
quizzes.explanation: This option follows the 'I feel [emotion] when [situation] because [reason]' formula and focuses on your experience without attacking the other person

quizzes.question: What are the three key parts of an effective 'I' statement?
options: Blame, accusation, demand
Feeling, situation, reason
Problem, person, punishment
Complaint, criticism, consequence
quizzes.explanation: An effective 'I' statement includes: how you FEEL, the SITUATION that triggers it, and the REASON why it affects you

concepts.title: The Art of Active Listening
concepts.definition: Active listening means giving your full attention and understanding the other person's point of view through focused attention and empathetic response
concepts.why_it_works: Listening with empathy builds trust and helps prevent miscommunication, making it easier to solve problems together

tutorial.good_story: When Alex shared concerns about an upcoming test, their friend Jamie put down their phone, made eye contact, and said: 'So you're worried because you missed last week's classes? That makes sense. What topics are you most concerned about?' Alex felt truly heard and supported.
tutorial.bad_story: While Emma was explaining why she was upset about being left out of weekend plans, her friend Kate kept scrolling Instagram, occasionally saying 'uh-huh' without looking up. Emma felt ignored and stopped sharing her feelings.

summary.summary_content: Active listening means giving full attention, not interrupting, and showing you understand through body language and paraphrasing. It's about listening to understand, not just to respond.
summary.next_chapter_intro: Good communication also means knowing your limits. Let's learn about setting healthy boundaries.

quizzes.question: Which of these behaviors shows active listening?
options: Planning your response while they talk
Checking your phone occasionally
Paraphrasing what they said to confirm understanding
Changing the subject to something similar that happened to you
quizzes.explanation: Paraphrasing shows you're truly listening and helps ensure you understood correctly

quizzes.question: Your friend is explaining why they're upset. What's the WORST listening response?
options: Can you help me understand what specifically bothered you?
That sounds really frustrating for you
You're overreacting, it's not that bad
So you felt left out when we made plans without you?
quizzes.explanation: Dismissing someone's feelings shows you're not listening with empathy and can damage trust in the relationship

concepts.title: Setting Boundaries and Saying 'No' Kindly
concepts.definition: Boundaries are personal limits that define what is okay or not okay for you in relationships, and can be physical or emotional
concepts.why_it_works: Clear boundaries protect your comfort and safety while respecting others, and true friends will understand and respect your honesty

tutorial.good_story: When friends pressured Lee to skip class, Lee calmly said: 'No thanks, I need to keep my attendance up for the team. You all have fun though!' The friends shrugged and respected the decision without pushing further.
tutorial.bad_story: Casey felt uncomfortable sharing their phone password but when their partner insisted, Casey gave in saying 'I guess... if you really want it...' and felt resentful and violated afterward, wishing they had stood firm.

summary.summary_content: You are the boss of your own body and choices. Boundaries can be physical or emotional, and saying 'no' kindly but firmly is your right. True friends will respect your boundaries.
summary.next_chapter_intro: Sometimes emotions make communication difficult. Let's explore how to recognize and manage feelings.

quizzes.question: A friend wants to copy your homework. Which response sets a clear boundary while being kind?
options: Sure, whatever, just take it
I'm not comfortable with that, but I can help explain the concepts to you
You're so lazy! Do your own work!
Maybe... I don't know... I guess if you really need it...
quizzes.explanation: This response clearly states your boundary while offering an alternative way to help

quizzes.question: What's a sign that someone is NOT respecting your boundaries?
options: They ask for clarification about your limits
They accept your 'no' without argument
They keep pushing after you've said no
They express their own boundaries too
quizzes.explanation: When someone continues to pressure you after you've set a boundary, they're not respecting your limits

concepts.title: Recognizing Feelings and Managing Emotions
concepts.definition: Emotional regulation involves recognizing what you're feeling and finding healthy ways to cope with intense emotions
concepts.why_it_works: Naming emotions helps regulate them by calming the part of the brain that causes stress, and pausing before reacting prevents conflicts from escalating

tutorial.good_story: During a heated discussion about group project roles, Sam felt anger rising. They said: 'I need a 5-minute break to collect my thoughts,' went for a quick walk, then returned calmer and suggested: 'Let's list everyone's strengths and divide tasks based on that.'
tutorial.bad_story: When criticized about their presentation, Jordan immediately snapped: 'Whatever! You think you're so perfect?' and stormed out, later regretting not taking time to process the feedback constructively.

summary.summary_content: Recognizing and naming emotions helps regulate them. When feelings are intense, pause before reacting, use healthy outlets like journaling or walking, and express feelings calmly using the skills you've learned.
summary.next_chapter_intro: You've completed the Communication and Boundaries module! Ready to apply these skills in your daily relationships?

quizzes.question: You feel yourself getting very angry during an argument. What's the best first step?
options: Say everything you're thinking immediately
Storm out without explanation
Take a deep breath and pause before responding
Pretend nothing is wrong
quizzes.explanation: Pausing helps you regulate emotions and prevents saying things you might regret

quizzes.question: According to brain science, what helps calm the stress response in your brain?
options: Ignoring your feelings
Naming and acknowledging your emotions
Blaming others for how you feel
Keeping feelings bottled up
quizzes.explanation: Research shows that putting feelings into words activates the brain's emotional regulation systems

reflection.module_summary: Think of a recent disagreement or tense situation you had with someone. How did you communicate your feelings? If you reacted on impulse or kept feelings inside, how might you handle it differently now using an 'I' statement or a pause to calm down?
reflection.learning_advice: Practice using 'I' statements in low-stakes situations first. It gets easier with practice!
